website_summaries.verdict: Best classic trivia game from a well-known brand that offers an excellent level of challenge.
pros: Trivia lovers praise the challenging questions and fun, broad range of trivia this classic Hasbro game has to offer
It also stands out for being playable for all generations and being an updated version with a beautiful design
The high quality of both the content and physical game make this a top choice
cons: A few felt this should come with boxes for the cards, and cards may tend to slump over

customer_reviews.title: Nothing to Do With Knowledge
customer_reviews.text: This used to be a great game and I thought I was buying the classic game...meaning classic questions. This is primarily boring questions about Twitter, apps and irrelevant things and I could care less about - what color some irrelevant millionaire's favorite color is? Geez. I have no interest in spending my time answering questions about. I played with 4 other adults (ages range) and a couple of teens. NONE of us were impressed and folded it up and got out another game. No, I do not recommend.
customer_reviews.author: little island studios

customer_reviews.title: Just ok
customer_reviews.text: As a dedicated Trivial Pursuit player (I have played with my family since I was old enough to roll the dice....over 30 years) - I find this version lacking. The questions seemed easier and less challenging than the Master Edition. I have purchased every 'general knowledge' addition since Genus and this was the first time that I felt the quality of questions went down. I would say that this version is good for people that aren't as avid players. The lack of box for the cards is frustrating too...especially if you are used to having it.
customer_reviews.author: GSD Lover

customer_reviews.title: Updated Classic Edition relevent and a lot fun for all ages
customer_reviews.text: After doing some research to find out which trivial pursuit game was most recently updated (2016), I purchased this classic edition for family game night. My teens LOVED the game as they were a good mix of questions covering at least six decades. We have played this a few times already, so I'm hoping they Hasbro comes out with a vol 2 deck. Honestly, its hard to find games for teens to stay engaged - this classic edition is still a keeper after all these years - esp since updated and relevant to this generation.
customer_reviews.author: RB13

customer_reviews.title: Not your mother’s trivial pursuit
customer_reviews.text: Remember when trivial pursuit had about 2000 cards, 1000 per box which you could play with friends over and over again? Not this edition... 400 cards, so make sure you read the same card as much as you can. This edition also lost the beautiful pictures on the board, and somehow brown became purple (and the categories got switched up). I still love tp, but if you’re looking to replace your 2000 something edition, you will be quite disappointed.
customer_reviews.author: Kari

customer_reviews.title: Questions not well categorized
customer_reviews.text: The game was exactly as expected, board, cards, and pieces all looked good, but doesn't compare to the original. Purchased this to replace our dated version. Turns out the categories are not done well and some of the questions are incredibly obscure. Mostly I felt like the every category was targeted to people plugged into pop culture. I grew very frustrated with the science category. "How many colors were in the original apple logo?" was one science questions that will go down in history with the family. It definitely belongs in the game just not in that category. Didn't return, kind of wishing I had. It will be a while before I wind up attempting it again.
customer_reviews.author: Steven Jones

customer_reviews.title: Pleased that the original game play is back!
customer_reviews.text: I have always loved this game and am so glad they have released another in its original format! Classic gameplay with new, relevant questions, which was a long time coming. Also, the game box design with its organized compartments for game pieces is a perk. This version, like more recent versions, gives some additional nuggets of knowledge on some answers, but unlike previous versions, it also incorporates cute, witty, or punny quips in some answers. Definately recommend for other trivia nerds like myself.
customer_reviews.author: JuliaR.B.

customer_reviews.title: Not as fun as we remembered
customer_reviews.text: Played with people in their 40s to 60s, and had to "cheat" outrageously to get through the game. The questions are much harder and more obscure than any of us remember.
customer_reviews.author: Sue E.

customer_reviews.title: Very Disappointed with the new updates!!!

customer_reviews.author: Dixie Barone

customer_reviews.title: Questions barely fit categories
customer_reviews.text: Don't be tricked by the packaging, this is not a re-release of the genus editing as i had hoped. Most of thequestions in this edition only marginally fit into their assigned categories. History is more modern politics than anything else, geography asks about fictional places or from a specific place, not questions about the place itself. Sport and leisure has very little from American football, baseball, basketball or hockey. I have several versions of trivial pursuit and this edition is the only one where i keep shaking my head wondering why questions aren't in a different category. Like the classic game play, hate the questions
customer_reviews.author: longhair

customer_reviews.title: Fun for Families
customer_reviews.text: I have the original genus edition from the 80's. My kids love the game, but hated the "old-fashioned" questions. So when this came on sale, my kids asked me to buy it. We play it as a family almost every week. Youngest is 11 but she can answer some questions. (The first time we played, she was actually ahead with 3 chips.) Some questions are multiple choice, which the original didn't have. My oldest says that makes those questions too easy, but still nearly all questions are not multiple choice. Another difference is the amount of question cards. The original set has 1000 or so. This set has a few hundred, so it's easier to remember the repeats.

customer_reviews.title: Hoping for better.

A side note any question about Justin Bieber is just plain bad..
customer_reviews.author: Sketch

customer_reviews.title: They’ve Updated Trivial Pursuit - Caution
customer_reviews.text: We returned this version of the game. I was a Trivial Pursuit whiz thirty years ago so when friends invited us over for a night of Trivial Pursuit we looked forward expectantly and purchased our own game. The game, unbeknownst to me, has been significantly updated. I am now that dinosaur who is slipping into the muck. Kind of like watching the news about some young popular actor and not knowing who they are - ouch. So . . . if you’re current on pop culture - great game; if you’re not, try to find a used old version and protect your ego.

customer_reviews.title: Meh, simply put

Because of that we got very frustrated playing this game because we just didn’t know any of the answers to some of these weird questions. I obviously don’t expect the questions to be easy but at the same time I don’t expect them to be unanswerable either.

product_meta.title: Hasbro Gaming Trivial Pursuit Game: Classic Edition
product_meta.description: Gather your friends to play the trivia game that started It all! The Classic Edition of this Trivial Pursuit Game is the same gameplay you know and love, only with a 1980's retro appearance! Featuring classic gameplay and gameboard, this game contains 2,400 questions in 6 categories: Geography, Entertainment, History, Art and Literature, Science and Nature, and Sports and Leisure. Players move around the board answering questions. When a player lands on a category space, they'll earn the corresponding colored wedge if they answer the question correctly. The first player to collect 6 different colored wedges and answer a final question correctly wins! Trivial Pursuit, the associated logo, the distinctive design of the gameboard, trivia cards, game tokens, and scoring wedges are trademarks of Hasbro. Hasbro Gaming and all related terms are trademarks of Hasbro.
